name: 1,4-bis[(trimethylsilyl)ethynyl]benzene
Reason: 1,4-Bis[(trimethylsilyl)ethynyl]benzene has a melting point influenced by its structural components relative to the base melting point of benzene, which is around 5°C. The presence of two additional phenyl groups contributes to an increase in molecular weight and van der Waals interactions, with an approximate increase of +20°C per group, totaling +40°C. The trimethylsilyl group introduces a rigid structure and raises the melting point due to the increased molecular weight and the presence of a bulky group, estimated at +10°C. The ethynyl group introduces a significant dipole, increasing intermolecular forces and melting point by approximately +50°C. The benzene ring introduces additional rigidity and pi-pi interactions, estimated at +20°C.
